Title: ‚ÄòBig Short‚Äô Michael Burry says Bitcoin worse than tulip bubble
URL: https://cryptobriefing.com/bitcoin-bubble-michael-burry-warning/
Time Published: 2025-12-02T16:59:51Z
Full Content:
Share this article Investor Michael Burry, best known for predicting the 2008 financial crisis, criticized Bitcoin on a podcast, comparing it to the historical tulip bubble and expressing skepticism about its valuation and utility. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not worth anything. Everybody‚Äôs accepted it. It‚Äôs the tulip bulb of our time,‚Äù Burry said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs worse than a tulip bulb, because this has enabled so much criminal activity to go deep under.‚Äù The hedge fund manager, who has recently made headlines for placing bearish bets against Nvidia (NVDA) and Palantir (PLTR), called the fact that Bitcoin reached $100,000 is ‚Äúthe most ridiculous thing.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat same people are sitting on TV talking about Bitcoin. They‚Äôre just casually, it‚Äôs $100,000, it‚Äôs down, now it‚Äôs $98,000,‚Äù he said. Despite dropping below $84,000 on Monday, Bitcoin reclaimed $90,000 after the US market opening. The digital asset was trading at around $90,600 at press time, up nearly 7% in the last 24 hours. It‚Äôs not the first time Michael Burry has criticized Bitcoin. In early 2021, he called it a ‚Äúspeculative bubble‚Äù comparable to the dot-com and housing bubbles, despite its growing relevance and popularity. Bitcoin has more than doubled in value since then. Title: Betrayed American Workers Expose Dark Underbelly Of H-1B Visa Scheme
URL: https://freerepublic.com/focus/f-bloggers/4355628/posts
Time Published: 2025-12-02T16:23:31Z
Full Content:
Skip to comments. Posted on 12/02/2025 8:23:31 AM PST by DFG They were promised lucrative and stable careers if they ‚Äúlearned to code‚Äù and earned a degree in software engineering. Instead, many Americans in the tech industry have been left disillusioned as they face mass layoffs and chronic unemployment ‚Äî a crisis they say stems from an addiction to cheap foreign labor pipelines that are made accessible through programs like H-1B, and are touted by companies as a way to hire the ‚Äúbest and brightest.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt this point, I‚Äôm doing something else,‚Äù Jonathan, a cybersecurity professional who is leaving the industry entirely out of frustration, told the Daily Caller News Foundation. ‚ÄúMy career is basically dead in the water because of these problems.‚Äù Jonathan lost his job in the industry in November 2024 and in the months since, he‚Äôs submitted well over 200 applications for tech-related positions in the Seattle area, but received a grand total of zero offers ‚Äî despite five years of experience and purportedly demonstrating high competency in every interview assessment thrown his way. He wished to be identified only by his first name out of fear of retribution from past and potential employers, as did most of the seven tech employees who spoke with the DCNF. Controversy surrounding the H-1B program, which very publicly split President Donald Trump‚Äôs inner circle shortly before he began his second term, has once again shot onto the national scene as the White House gives mixed signals on the program‚Äôs benefits. The issue has proven divisive for the Republican leader, who was elected to office on a pro-worker platform, but also has powerful allies in the tech world. When reached for comment, the White House referred to recent statements made by press secretary Karoline Leavitt. ‚ÄúThe president does not support American workers being replaced,‚Äù Leavitt told a group of reporters earlier in November. ‚ÄúThe president has a very nuanced, common-sense opinion on this issue ‚Ä¶ but ultimately [he] wants to see American workers in those jobs‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs been a lot of misunderstanding of the president‚Äôs position.‚Äù ‚ÄòDisillusioned‚Äô Public data suggests that many American engineers are being passed over for foreign workers. Throughout 2025, major technology companies such as Microsoft, Meta, Amazon and Intel underwent layoffs ‚Äî continuing what has been a years-long trend in the industry. The workers interviewed by the DCNF were not employed at these specific tech companies. Roughly 428,000 tech workers lost their job between 2022 and 2023, and a total of 384 tech companies handed pink slips to roughly 124,000 workers in 2024, according to the Institute for Sound Public Policy (ISPP). While H-1Bs have an outsized influence on the tech world, workers across all major industries are impacted by imported foreign labor. The flow of H-1B workers into the U.S. has largely kept apace despite these mass layoffs, with the ISPP finding that the number of H-1B visa workers has grown 80% since the Great Recession low in 2011. Experts estimate that nearly 660,000 H-1B workers were living in the U.S. in October 2024. Established by Congress in 1990, the H-1B program was originally intended to utilize ‚Äúhighly specialized‚Äù foreign labor, according to the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. Although it‚Äôs a nonimmigrant visa, H-1B holders can eventually become eligible to apply for legal permanent residence, allowing them to stay in the country indefinitely. The tech industry dominates the use of H-1Bs, with tech companies accounting for nearly 70% of H-1B petitions annually, according to Nation Connections, a site dedicated to helping individuals navigate immigration laws in different countries. Other American-born tech workers have shared similar experiences to Jonathan‚Äôs, and have stayed silent due to fear of retaliation. ‚ÄúI do feel kind of disillusioned with the industry,‚Äù said Riley, who graduated with a software engineering degree in 2021. ‚ÄúSoftware engineers have a higher unemployment rate right now than art history majors.‚Äù Art history majors have a 3% unemployment rate, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which compiled data released in February. Computer engineering majors, on the other hand, currently suffer from a 7.5% unemployment rate. Riley said he noticed a monumental shift in the hiring practices of an Austin-based company he worked at for several years. He claims the company ‚Äî which had faced consistent complaints from engineers about pay ‚Äî increasingly staffed its engineering departments with employees from South America and eventually established an office in Colombia to better utilize the continent‚Äôs workforce. ‚ÄúI believe that that was done in order to, you know, reduce their labor costs so that they could get engineers without negotiating with [the American-born engineers] or caving to their demands,‚Äù Riley said. Jonathan described a similar situation after the California-based company he worked for introduced an India development center. Roughly six months after the center was launched, he said the company stopped hiring outside of India altogether. About a year after he left, Jonathan‚Äôs former coworker informed him that around half of the company‚Äôs security personnel was let go. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to lose advancement opportunities, you‚Äôre going to have HR problems and you‚Äôre going to be not a team player if you don‚Äôt advocate with open arms the idea of an Indian development center being opened up to your company or a billion H-1Bs flooding the market,‚Äù Jonathan said about the situation he was facing and the continued pressure to not speak out. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre All In The Process Of Being Replaced‚Äô India stands far above any other nation as the top source of foreign labor, making up 72% of all H-1B recipients between October 2022 and September 2023, per a March 2024 report from the Department of Homeland Security. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all in the process of being replaced,‚Äù John, who worked for an insurance company in Connecticut, told the DCNF. John said there were around 350 IT employees ‚Äî all purportedly American ‚Äî at his company when he first began in 2006. Throughout his decade at the company, he claims they were all steadily booted out in favor of foreign workers. ‚ÄúMost of the time they had them train their Indian replacements before they left as a condition of receiving their severance,‚Äù he told the DCNF. ‚ÄúSo what I saw over a period of time was a whole bunch of lives being destroyed.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the younger kids can‚Äôt find employment,‚Äù John said of the industry. ‚ÄúThey spent a whole bunch of money learning all of this stuff ‚Äî computer programs, cloud platforms, this that the other thing ‚Äî but they can‚Äôt find work.‚Äù The tech employees who spoke to the DCNF are struggling to find work in the U.S. at a time when college debt has skyrocketed to historical highs. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. I also like your statement that, for national economy purposes (and I'd add for national security purposes), it'd be dangerous for us to tell future workers to not be our tech experts. Just like we need to get non-English speaking immigrants from driving 18-wheelers, we need most of our tech to be Americans. Now that the H1B problem is impacting both tech and trade jobs, I hope that Americans will rally against overuse of H1B's. 11 posted on 12/02/2025 8:51:53 AM PST by Tell It Right (1 Thessalonians 5:21 -- Put everything to the test, hold fast to that which is true.) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy The biggest problem with the IT field is that it has two characteristics that make it fertile ground for a "race to the bottom" type of business/employment environment: 1. Like almost any STEM field, it is universal in nature and therefore easily transferable across borders. 2. It doesn't require professional licensure. The second one is a big one, because it's what sets an IT professional apart from, say, a medical doctor, a professional engineer, lawyer, or a CPA. The educational requirements for licensure in some of these fields represent a high barrier to entry for foreigners who might otherwise be qualified to do the work. 12 posted on 12/02/2025 8:57:07 AM PST by Alberta's Child ("There's somebody new and he sure ain't no rodeo man.") I worked with a French H1B who was excellent, but the generic Asian programmers I worked with were all average, at best. Resume stuffing, massive use of AI and earlier computer helps. Lots of output (sometimes) but cludgy code that creates more problems than it solves. Kinda like modern M$ ‚Ä¶ 13 posted on 12/02/2025 8:59:17 AM PST by texas booster (Join FreeRepublic's Folding@Home team (Team # 36120) Cure Alzheimer's!) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: DFG I want my... I want my... I want my H 1 B.... Look at them yo-yos. However, I dearly loved being a COBL programmer and really hated business analysis. But it paid the bills. 15 posted on 12/02/2025 9:09:03 AM PST by cuban leaf [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy Same here. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search Bloggers & Personal Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Instead, many Americans in the tech industry have been left disillusioned as they face mass layoffs and chronic unemployment ‚Äî a crisis they say stems from an addiction to cheap foreign labor pipelines that are made accessible through programs like H-1B, and are touted by companies as a way to hire the ‚Äúbest and brightest.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt this point, I‚Äôm doing something else,‚Äù Jonathan, a cybersecurity professional who is leaving the industry entirely out of frustration, told the Daily Caller News Foundation. ‚ÄúMy career is basically dead in the water because of these problems.‚Äù Jonathan lost his job in the industry in November 2024 and in the months since, he‚Äôs submitted well over 200 applications for tech-related positions in the Seattle area, but received a grand total of zero offers ‚Äî despite five years of experience and purportedly demonstrating high competency in every interview assessment thrown his way. He wished to be identified only by his first name out of fear of retribution from past and potential employers, as did most of the seven tech employees who spoke with the DCNF. Controversy surrounding the H-1B program, which very publicly split President Donald Trump‚Äôs inner circle shortly before he began his second term, has once again shot onto the national scene as the White House gives mixed signals on the program‚Äôs benefits. The issue has proven divisive for the Republican leader, who was elected to office on a pro-worker platform, but also has powerful allies in the tech world. When reached for comment, the White House referred to recent statements made by press secretary Karoline Leavitt. ‚ÄúThe president does not support American workers being replaced,‚Äù Leavitt told a group of reporters earlier in November. ‚ÄúThe president has a very nuanced, common-sense opinion on this issue ‚Ä¶ but ultimately [he] wants to see American workers in those jobs‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs been a lot of misunderstanding of the president‚Äôs position.‚Äù ‚ÄòDisillusioned‚Äô Public data suggests that many American engineers are being passed over for foreign workers. Throughout 2025, major technology companies such as Microsoft, Meta, Amazon and Intel underwent layoffs ‚Äî continuing what has been a years-long trend in the industry. The workers interviewed by the DCNF were not employed at these specific tech companies. Roughly 428,000 tech workers lost their job between 2022 and 2023, and a total of 384 tech companies handed pink slips to roughly 124,000 workers in 2024, according to the Institute for Sound Public Policy (ISPP). While H-1Bs have an outsized influence on the tech world, workers across all major industries are impacted by imported foreign labor. The flow of H-1B workers into the U.S. has largely kept apace despite these mass layoffs, with the ISPP finding that the number of H-1B visa workers has grown 80% since the Great Recession low in 2011. Experts estimate that nearly 660,000 H-1B workers were living in the U.S. in October 2024. Established by Congress in 1990, the H-1B program was originally intended to utilize ‚Äúhighly specialized‚Äù foreign labor, according to the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. Although it‚Äôs a nonimmigrant visa, H-1B holders can eventually become eligible to apply for legal permanent residence, allowing them to stay in the country indefinitely. The tech industry dominates the use of H-1Bs, with tech companies accounting for nearly 70% of H-1B petitions annually, according to Nation Connections, a site dedicated to helping individuals navigate immigration laws in different countries. Other American-born tech workers have shared similar experiences to Jonathan‚Äôs, and have stayed silent due to fear of retaliation. ‚ÄúI do feel kind of disillusioned with the industry,‚Äù said Riley, who graduated with a software engineering degree in 2021. ‚ÄúSoftware engineers have a higher unemployment rate right now than art history majors.‚Äù Art history majors have a 3% unemployment rate, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which compiled data released in February. Computer engineering majors, on the other hand, currently suffer from a 7.5% unemployment rate. Riley said he noticed a monumental shift in the hiring practices of an Austin-based company he worked at for several years. He claims the company ‚Äî which had faced consistent complaints from engineers about pay ‚Äî increasingly staffed its engineering departments with employees from South America and eventually established an office in Colombia to better utilize the continent‚Äôs workforce. ‚ÄúI believe that that was done in order to, you know, reduce their labor costs so that they could get engineers without negotiating with [the American-born engineers] or caving to their demands,‚Äù Riley said. Jonathan described a similar situation after the California-based company he worked for introduced an India development center. Roughly six months after the center was launched, he said the company stopped hiring outside of India altogether. About a year after he left, Jonathan‚Äôs former coworker informed him that around half of the company‚Äôs security personnel was let go. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to lose advancement opportunities, you‚Äôre going to have HR problems and you‚Äôre going to be not a team player if you don‚Äôt advocate with open arms the idea of an Indian development center being opened up to your company or a billion H-1Bs flooding the market,‚Äù Jonathan said about the situation he was facing and the continued pressure to not speak out. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre All In The Process Of Being Replaced‚Äô India stands far above any other nation as the top source of foreign labor, making up 72% of all H-1B recipients between October 2022 and September 2023, per a March 2024 report from the Department of Homeland Security. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all in the process of being replaced,‚Äù John, who worked for an insurance company in Connecticut, told the DCNF. John said there were around 350 IT employees ‚Äî all purportedly American ‚Äî at his company when he first began in 2006. Throughout his decade at the company, he claims they were all steadily booted out in favor of foreign workers. ‚ÄúMost of the time they had them train their Indian replacements before they left as a condition of receiving their severance,‚Äù he told the DCNF. ‚ÄúSo what I saw over a period of time was a whole bunch of lives being destroyed.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the younger kids can‚Äôt find employment,‚Äù John said of the industry. ‚ÄúThey spent a whole bunch of money learning all of this stuff ‚Äî computer programs, cloud platforms, this that the other thing ‚Äî but they can‚Äôt find work.‚Äù The tech employees who spoke to the DCNF are struggling to find work in the U.S. at a time when college debt has skyrocketed to historical highs. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. It‚Äôs a pretty foolish career path at this point. But, from the view of a national economy of a developed nation ‚Äî you REALLY want your citizens to pursue technology and grow your own economy with your own people and keep all the skills, money, and knowledge right here at home. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy The biggest problem with the IT field is that it has two characteristics that make it fertile ground for a "race to the bottom" type of business/employment environment: 1. Like almost any STEM field, it is universal in nature and therefore easily transferable across borders. 2. It doesn't require professional licensure. The second one is a big one, because it's what sets an IT professional apart from, say, a medical doctor, a professional engineer, lawyer, or a CPA. The educational requirements for licensure in some of these fields represent a high barrier to entry for foreigners who might otherwise be qualified to do the work. 12 posted on 12/02/2025 8:57:07 AM PST by Alberta's Child ("There's somebody new and he sure ain't no rodeo man.") Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search Bloggers & Personal Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Jonathan lost his job in the industry in November 2024 and in the months since, he‚Äôs submitted well over 200 applications for tech-related positions in the Seattle area, but received a grand total of zero offers ‚Äî despite five years of experience and purportedly demonstrating high competency in every interview assessment thrown his way. He wished to be identified only by his first name out of fear of retribution from past and potential employers, as did most of the seven tech employees who spoke with the DCNF. Controversy surrounding the H-1B program, which very publicly split President Donald Trump‚Äôs inner circle shortly before he began his second term, has once again shot onto the national scene as the White House gives mixed signals on the program‚Äôs benefits. The issue has proven divisive for the Republican leader, who was elected to office on a pro-worker platform, but also has powerful allies in the tech world. When reached for comment, the White House referred to recent statements made by press secretary Karoline Leavitt. ‚ÄúThe president does not support American workers being replaced,‚Äù Leavitt told a group of reporters earlier in November. ‚ÄúThe president has a very nuanced, common-sense opinion on this issue ‚Ä¶ but ultimately [he] wants to see American workers in those jobs‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs been a lot of misunderstanding of the president‚Äôs position.‚Äù ‚ÄòDisillusioned‚Äô Public data suggests that many American engineers are being passed over for foreign workers. Throughout 2025, major technology companies such as Microsoft, Meta, Amazon and Intel underwent layoffs ‚Äî continuing what has been a years-long trend in the industry. The workers interviewed by the DCNF were not employed at these specific tech companies. Roughly 428,000 tech workers lost their job between 2022 and 2023, and a total of 384 tech companies handed pink slips to roughly 124,000 workers in 2024, according to the Institute for Sound Public Policy (ISPP). While H-1Bs have an outsized influence on the tech world, workers across all major industries are impacted by imported foreign labor. The flow of H-1B workers into the U.S. has largely kept apace despite these mass layoffs, with the ISPP finding that the number of H-1B visa workers has grown 80% since the Great Recession low in 2011. Experts estimate that nearly 660,000 H-1B workers were living in the U.S. in October 2024. Established by Congress in 1990, the H-1B program was originally intended to utilize ‚Äúhighly specialized‚Äù foreign labor, according to the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. Although it‚Äôs a nonimmigrant visa, H-1B holders can eventually become eligible to apply for legal permanent residence, allowing them to stay in the country indefinitely. The tech industry dominates the use of H-1Bs, with tech companies accounting for nearly 70% of H-1B petitions annually, according to Nation Connections, a site dedicated to helping individuals navigate immigration laws in different countries. Other American-born tech workers have shared similar experiences to Jonathan‚Äôs, and have stayed silent due to fear of retaliation. ‚ÄúI do feel kind of disillusioned with the industry,‚Äù said Riley, who graduated with a software engineering degree in 2021. ‚ÄúSoftware engineers have a higher unemployment rate right now than art history majors.‚Äù Art history majors have a 3% unemployment rate, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which compiled data released in February. Computer engineering majors, on the other hand, currently suffer from a 7.5% unemployment rate. Riley said he noticed a monumental shift in the hiring practices of an Austin-based company he worked at for several years. He claims the company ‚Äî which had faced consistent complaints from engineers about pay ‚Äî increasingly staffed its engineering departments with employees from South America and eventually established an office in Colombia to better utilize the continent‚Äôs workforce. ‚ÄúI believe that that was done in order to, you know, reduce their labor costs so that they could get engineers without negotiating with [the American-born engineers] or caving to their demands,‚Äù Riley said. Jonathan described a similar situation after the California-based company he worked for introduced an India development center. Roughly six months after the center was launched, he said the company stopped hiring outside of India altogether. About a year after he left, Jonathan‚Äôs former coworker informed him that around half of the company‚Äôs security personnel was let go. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to lose advancement opportunities, you‚Äôre going to have HR problems and you‚Äôre going to be not a team player if you don‚Äôt advocate with open arms the idea of an Indian development center being opened up to your company or a billion H-1Bs flooding the market,‚Äù Jonathan said about the situation he was facing and the continued pressure to not speak out. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre All In The Process Of Being Replaced‚Äô India stands far above any other nation as the top source of foreign labor, making up 72% of all H-1B recipients between October 2022 and September 2023, per a March 2024 report from the Department of Homeland Security. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all in the process of being replaced,‚Äù John, who worked for an insurance company in Connecticut, told the DCNF. John said there were around 350 IT employees ‚Äî all purportedly American ‚Äî at his company when he first began in 2006. Throughout his decade at the company, he claims they were all steadily booted out in favor of foreign workers. ‚ÄúMost of the time they had them train their Indian replacements before they left as a condition of receiving their severance,‚Äù he told the DCNF. ‚ÄúSo what I saw over a period of time was a whole bunch of lives being destroyed.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the younger kids can‚Äôt find employment,‚Äù John said of the industry. ‚ÄúThey spent a whole bunch of money learning all of this stuff ‚Äî computer programs, cloud platforms, this that the other thing ‚Äî but they can‚Äôt find work.‚Äù The tech employees who spoke to the DCNF are struggling to find work in the U.S. at a time when college debt has skyrocketed to historical highs. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy The biggest problem with the IT field is that it has two characteristics that make it fertile ground for a "race to the bottom" type of business/employment environment: 1. Like almost any STEM field, it is universal in nature and therefore easily transferable across borders. 2. It doesn't require professional licensure. The second one is a big one, because it's what sets an IT professional apart from, say, a medical doctor, a professional engineer, lawyer, or a CPA. The educational requirements for licensure in some of these fields represent a high barrier to entry for foreigners who might otherwise be qualified to do the work. 12 posted on 12/02/2025 8:57:07 AM PST by Alberta's Child ("There's somebody new and he sure ain't no rodeo man.") [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: DFG One of Mr.GG2‚Äôs friends has been out of work for over 5 years due to this carp. He‚Äôs A coder and previously made over $200,000 per year. Now he‚Äôs blackballed. Being ultra conservative and 100% American isn‚Äôt cool. 19 posted on 12/02/2025 9:26:21 AM PST by Georgia Girl 2 (The only purpose of a pistol is to fight your way back to the rifle you should never have dropped) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: DFG Why do people act like H-1B is something new... 20 posted on 12/02/2025 9:26:51 AM PST by Sacajaweau [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] Navigation: use the links below to view more comments. first 1-20, 21-38 next last Disclaimer: Opinions posted on Free Republic are those of the individual posters and do not necessarily represent the opinion of Free Republic or its management. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search Bloggers & Personal Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson He wished to be identified only by his first name out of fear of retribution from past and potential employers, as did most of the seven tech employees who spoke with the DCNF. Controversy surrounding the H-1B program, which very publicly split President Donald Trump‚Äôs inner circle shortly before he began his second term, has once again shot onto the national scene as the White House gives mixed signals on the program‚Äôs benefits. The issue has proven divisive for the Republican leader, who was elected to office on a pro-worker platform, but also has powerful allies in the tech world. When reached for comment, the White House referred to recent statements made by press secretary Karoline Leavitt. ‚ÄúThe president does not support American workers being replaced,‚Äù Leavitt told a group of reporters earlier in November. ‚ÄúThe president has a very nuanced, common-sense opinion on this issue ‚Ä¶ but ultimately [he] wants to see American workers in those jobs‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs been a lot of misunderstanding of the president‚Äôs position.‚Äù ‚ÄòDisillusioned‚Äô Public data suggests that many American engineers are being passed over for foreign workers. Throughout 2025, major technology companies such as Microsoft, Meta, Amazon and Intel underwent layoffs ‚Äî continuing what has been a years-long trend in the industry. The workers interviewed by the DCNF were not employed at these specific tech companies. Roughly 428,000 tech workers lost their job between 2022 and 2023, and a total of 384 tech companies handed pink slips to roughly 124,000 workers in 2024, according to the Institute for Sound Public Policy (ISPP). While H-1Bs have an outsized influence on the tech world, workers across all major industries are impacted by imported foreign labor. The flow of H-1B workers into the U.S. has largely kept apace despite these mass layoffs, with the ISPP finding that the number of H-1B visa workers has grown 80% since the Great Recession low in 2011. Experts estimate that nearly 660,000 H-1B workers were living in the U.S. in October 2024. Established by Congress in 1990, the H-1B program was originally intended to utilize ‚Äúhighly specialized‚Äù foreign labor, according to the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. Although it‚Äôs a nonimmigrant visa, H-1B holders can eventually become eligible to apply for legal permanent residence, allowing them to stay in the country indefinitely. The tech industry dominates the use of H-1Bs, with tech companies accounting for nearly 70% of H-1B petitions annually, according to Nation Connections, a site dedicated to helping individuals navigate immigration laws in different countries. Other American-born tech workers have shared similar experiences to Jonathan‚Äôs, and have stayed silent due to fear of retaliation. ‚ÄúI do feel kind of disillusioned with the industry,‚Äù said Riley, who graduated with a software engineering degree in 2021. ‚ÄúSoftware engineers have a higher unemployment rate right now than art history majors.‚Äù Art history majors have a 3% unemployment rate, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which compiled data released in February. Computer engineering majors, on the other hand, currently suffer from a 7.5% unemployment rate. Riley said he noticed a monumental shift in the hiring practices of an Austin-based company he worked at for several years. He claims the company ‚Äî which had faced consistent complaints from engineers about pay ‚Äî increasingly staffed its engineering departments with employees from South America and eventually established an office in Colombia to better utilize the continent‚Äôs workforce. ‚ÄúI believe that that was done in order to, you know, reduce their labor costs so that they could get engineers without negotiating with [the American-born engineers] or caving to their demands,‚Äù Riley said. Jonathan described a similar situation after the California-based company he worked for introduced an India development center. Roughly six months after the center was launched, he said the company stopped hiring outside of India altogether. About a year after he left, Jonathan‚Äôs former coworker informed him that around half of the company‚Äôs security personnel was let go. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to lose advancement opportunities, you‚Äôre going to have HR problems and you‚Äôre going to be not a team player if you don‚Äôt advocate with open arms the idea of an Indian development center being opened up to your company or a billion H-1Bs flooding the market,‚Äù Jonathan said about the situation he was facing and the continued pressure to not speak out. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre All In The Process Of Being Replaced‚Äô India stands far above any other nation as the top source of foreign labor, making up 72% of all H-1B recipients between October 2022 and September 2023, per a March 2024 report from the Department of Homeland Security. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all in the process of being replaced,‚Äù John, who worked for an insurance company in Connecticut, told the DCNF. John said there were around 350 IT employees ‚Äî all purportedly American ‚Äî at his company when he first began in 2006. Throughout his decade at the company, he claims they were all steadily booted out in favor of foreign workers. ‚ÄúMost of the time they had them train their Indian replacements before they left as a condition of receiving their severance,‚Äù he told the DCNF. ‚ÄúSo what I saw over a period of time was a whole bunch of lives being destroyed.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the younger kids can‚Äôt find employment,‚Äù John said of the industry. ‚ÄúThey spent a whole bunch of money learning all of this stuff ‚Äî computer programs, cloud platforms, this that the other thing ‚Äî but they can‚Äôt find work.‚Äù The tech employees who spoke to the DCNF are struggling to find work in the U.S. at a time when college debt has skyrocketed to historical highs. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. It did work out OK for me, but I got in decades ago and have now retired. They can offshore your job. They can bring foreigners here to take away your job. Your job can be automated. Your job can be eliminated by fools upstairs who don‚Äôt understand why technology is important. And technology changes all the time ‚Äî it‚Äôs real work to stay up to speed, and if you don‚Äôt, they will bring in a new foreigner who just graduated with the latest skill and who will work cheap. It‚Äôs a pretty foolish career path at this point. But, from the view of a national economy of a developed nation ‚Äî you REALLY want your citizens to pursue technology and grow your own economy with your own people and keep all the skills, money, and knowledge right here at home. The government has to make some serious changes to make technology a good field again. 3 posted on 12/02/2025 8:42:38 AM PST by ClearCase_guy (Democrats seek power through cheating and assassination. [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy The biggest problem with the IT field is that it has two characteristics that make it fertile ground for a "race to the bottom" type of business/employment environment: 1. Like almost any STEM field, it is universal in nature and therefore easily transferable across borders. 2. It doesn't require professional licensure. The second one is a big one, because it's what sets an IT professional apart from, say, a medical doctor, a professional engineer, lawyer, or a CPA. The educational requirements for licensure in some of these fields represent a high barrier to entry for foreigners who might otherwise be qualified to do the work. 12 posted on 12/02/2025 8:57:07 AM PST by Alberta's Child ("There's somebody new and he sure ain't no rodeo man.") [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy Agreed. I say that as a quasi-retired code jockey myself. It was a great field to go into and it's probably not anymore. [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy The biggest problem with the IT field is that it has two characteristics that make it fertile ground for a "race to the bottom" type of business/employment environment: 1. Like almost any STEM field, it is universal in nature and therefore easily transferable across borders. 2. It doesn't require professional licensure. The second one is a big one, because it's what sets an IT professional apart from, say, a medical doctor, a professional engineer, lawyer, or a CPA. The educational requirements for licensure in some of these fields represent a high barrier to entry for foreigners who might otherwise be qualified to do the work. 12 posted on 12/02/2025 8:57:07 AM PST by Alberta's Child ("There's somebody new and he sure ain't no rodeo man.") Lots of output (sometimes) but cludgy code that creates more problems than it solves. Kinda like modern M$ ‚Ä¶ 13 posted on 12/02/2025 8:59:17 AM PST by texas booster (Join FreeRepublic's Folding@Home team (Team # 36120) Cure Alzheimer's!) However, I dearly loved being a COBL programmer and really hated business analysis. But it paid the bills. 15 posted on 12/02/2025 9:09:03 AM PST by cuban leaf [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy Same here. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search Bloggers & Personal Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson When reached for comment, the White House referred to recent statements made by press secretary Karoline Leavitt. ‚ÄúThe president does not support American workers being replaced,‚Äù Leavitt told a group of reporters earlier in November. ‚ÄúThe president has a very nuanced, common-sense opinion on this issue ‚Ä¶ but ultimately [he] wants to see American workers in those jobs‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs been a lot of misunderstanding of the president‚Äôs position.‚Äù ‚ÄòDisillusioned‚Äô Public data suggests that many American engineers are being passed over for foreign workers. Throughout 2025, major technology companies such as Microsoft, Meta, Amazon and Intel underwent layoffs ‚Äî continuing what has been a years-long trend in the industry. The workers interviewed by the DCNF were not employed at these specific tech companies. Roughly 428,000 tech workers lost their job between 2022 and 2023, and a total of 384 tech companies handed pink slips to roughly 124,000 workers in 2024, according to the Institute for Sound Public Policy (ISPP). While H-1Bs have an outsized influence on the tech world, workers across all major industries are impacted by imported foreign labor. The flow of H-1B workers into the U.S. has largely kept apace despite these mass layoffs, with the ISPP finding that the number of H-1B visa workers has grown 80% since the Great Recession low in 2011. Experts estimate that nearly 660,000 H-1B workers were living in the U.S. in October 2024. Established by Congress in 1990, the H-1B program was originally intended to utilize ‚Äúhighly specialized‚Äù foreign labor, according to the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. Although it‚Äôs a nonimmigrant visa, H-1B holders can eventually become eligible to apply for legal permanent residence, allowing them to stay in the country indefinitely. The tech industry dominates the use of H-1Bs, with tech companies accounting for nearly 70% of H-1B petitions annually, according to Nation Connections, a site dedicated to helping individuals navigate immigration laws in different countries. Other American-born tech workers have shared similar experiences to Jonathan‚Äôs, and have stayed silent due to fear of retaliation. ‚ÄúI do feel kind of disillusioned with the industry,‚Äù said Riley, who graduated with a software engineering degree in 2021. ‚ÄúSoftware engineers have a higher unemployment rate right now than art history majors.‚Äù Art history majors have a 3% unemployment rate, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which compiled data released in February. Computer engineering majors, on the other hand, currently suffer from a 7.5% unemployment rate. Riley said he noticed a monumental shift in the hiring practices of an Austin-based company he worked at for several years. He claims the company ‚Äî which had faced consistent complaints from engineers about pay ‚Äî increasingly staffed its engineering departments with employees from South America and eventually established an office in Colombia to better utilize the continent‚Äôs workforce. ‚ÄúI believe that that was done in order to, you know, reduce their labor costs so that they could get engineers without negotiating with [the American-born engineers] or caving to their demands,‚Äù Riley said. Jonathan described a similar situation after the California-based company he worked for introduced an India development center. Roughly six months after the center was launched, he said the company stopped hiring outside of India altogether. About a year after he left, Jonathan‚Äôs former coworker informed him that around half of the company‚Äôs security personnel was let go. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to lose advancement opportunities, you‚Äôre going to have HR problems and you‚Äôre going to be not a team player if you don‚Äôt advocate with open arms the idea of an Indian development center being opened up to your company or a billion H-1Bs flooding the market,‚Äù Jonathan said about the situation he was facing and the continued pressure to not speak out. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre All In The Process Of Being Replaced‚Äô India stands far above any other nation as the top source of foreign labor, making up 72% of all H-1B recipients between October 2022 and September 2023, per a March 2024 report from the Department of Homeland Security. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all in the process of being replaced,‚Äù John, who worked for an insurance company in Connecticut, told the DCNF. John said there were around 350 IT employees ‚Äî all purportedly American ‚Äî at his company when he first began in 2006. Throughout his decade at the company, he claims they were all steadily booted out in favor of foreign workers. ‚ÄúMost of the time they had them train their Indian replacements before they left as a condition of receiving their severance,‚Äù he told the DCNF. ‚ÄúSo what I saw over a period of time was a whole bunch of lives being destroyed.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the younger kids can‚Äôt find employment,‚Äù John said of the industry. ‚ÄúThey spent a whole bunch of money learning all of this stuff ‚Äî computer programs, cloud platforms, this that the other thing ‚Äî but they can‚Äôt find work.‚Äù The tech employees who spoke to the DCNF are struggling to find work in the U.S. at a time when college debt has skyrocketed to historical highs. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. It did work out OK for me, but I got in decades ago and have now retired. They can offshore your job. They can bring foreigners here to take away your job. Your job can be automated. Your job can be eliminated by fools upstairs who don‚Äôt understand why technology is important. And technology changes all the time ‚Äî it‚Äôs real work to stay up to speed, and if you don‚Äôt, they will bring in a new foreigner who just graduated with the latest skill and who will work cheap. It‚Äôs a pretty foolish career path at this point. But, from the view of a national economy of a developed nation ‚Äî you REALLY want your citizens to pursue technology and grow your own economy with your own people and keep all the skills, money, and knowledge right here at home. The government has to make some serious changes to make technology a good field again. 3 posted on 12/02/2025 8:42:38 AM PST by ClearCase_guy (Democrats seek power through cheating and assassination. John said there were around 350 IT employees ‚Äî all purportedly American ‚Äî at his company when he first began in 2006. Throughout his decade at the company, he claims they were all steadily booted out in favor of foreign workers. ‚ÄúMost of the time they had them train their Indian replacements before they left as a condition of receiving their severance,‚Äù he told the DCNF. ‚ÄúSo what I saw over a period of time was a whole bunch of lives being destroyed.‚Äù ‚ÄúA lot of the younger kids can‚Äôt find employment,‚Äù John said of the industry. ‚ÄúThey spent a whole bunch of money learning all of this stuff ‚Äî computer programs, cloud platforms, this that the other thing ‚Äî but they can‚Äôt find work.‚Äù The tech employees who spoke to the DCNF are struggling to find work in the U.S. at a time when college debt has skyrocketed to historical highs. Roughly 44 million Americans owe more than $1.7 trillion in student debt, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Engineering degrees in general are consistently ranked as one of the costliest to earn. Like his coworkers before him, John was ultimately ‚Äúreplaced‚Äù and handed a severance agreement that forbids him from discussing the matter publicly. ‚ÄúComing home to western Washington from Alaska, I assumed that finding a better-paying job would be no issue ‚Äî we are home to some of the nation‚Äôs largest tech companies,‚Äù Luke Hawthorne told the DCNF. ‚ÄúI spent nearly a year over 2022 and 2023 searching for my current job, a job which pays me about the same as I was making before.‚Äù While Hawthorne still considers himself lucky to be employed, he said his current salary ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt even approach‚Äù the threshold it takes to afford a home in his area of Washington State. His home state‚Äôs software developer workforce grew by more than 16% through H-1B certifications over just a 9-month period, with 83% of these positions approved at or below Washington State‚Äôs median wage, according to public data he analyzed and shared with the DCNF. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äòbest and brightest‚Äô argument simply doesn‚Äôt square with how the program is being used,‚Äù Hawthorne said. ‚ÄúAnother important aspect of it is that you aren‚Äôt competing just with the new arrivals, but with all of the tech workers who have been replaced ‚Äî I have friends with talent and experience who have been out of work for years.‚Äù Many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF have since become involved with U.S. Tech Workers, an advocacy group that highlights the plight of American employees negatively affected by the H-1B program and pushes Washington, D.C., for change. Trump, who has implemented some of the most hawkish immigration policies since returning to office, has appeared to give mixed signals on the issue as major players within his own inner circle disagree over reform. The president‚Äôs coalition appeared fragmented in the weeks leading up to his second presidential inauguration, with business magnate Elon Musk touting H-1Bs in December 2024 and Vivek Ramaswamy suggesting that the U.S. needs foreign talent because American culture ‚Äúvenerated mediocrity over excellence.‚Äù Georgia GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a former a top Trump ally who is resigning from Congress, said in November she would introduce legislation completely phasing out the H-1B program, accusing tech companies of abusing the system at the expense of Americans. Trump initially appeared to side with the pro-H-1B faction, declaring in December 2024 that he was ‚Äúa believer‚Äù in the visa program. In what appeared to be a major shift into the pro-American worker camp, Trump in September signed a proclamation slapping a $100,000 fee on all new H-1B applications, but opponents of the program have criticized the fee‚Äôs limitations and workarounds. Earlier in November, Trump once again publicly touted the need for H-1Bs to import foreign workers. As Washington, D.C., continues to debate the value of H-1Bs, American tech workers say they‚Äôve been left out to dry. ‚ÄúI graduated college seven years ago and I remember in high school them telling us, ‚Äòlearn to code and you‚Äôll have a good job,'‚Äù Joseph Ibrahim, an unemployed tech worker based in Florida, told the DCNF. ‚ÄúWell, it turns out they outsource the coding jobs also, not just the manufacturing jobs.‚Äù Ibrahim got a degree in information systems, business analytics and information systems, but has been struggling to find work since April. Unlike many of the tech workers who spoke to the DCNF, he had no problem being identified by his full name. ‚ÄúWhat are they gonna do?‚Äù Ibrahim asked. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre already not hiring me.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know, if I went into college and on the pamphlet, there were like, ‚Äòpros and cons of studying something in computer science: you may have to train your replacement at some point in your career,‚Äô I would have never studied this,‚Äù he said. But, from the view of a national economy of a developed nation ‚Äî you REALLY want your citizens to pursue technology and grow your own economy with your own people and keep all the skills, money, and knowledge right here at home. [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: ClearCase_guy The biggest problem with the IT field is that it has two characteristics that make it fertile ground for a "race to the bottom" type of business/employment environment: 1. Like almost any STEM field, it is universal in nature and therefore easily transferable across borders. 2. It doesn't require professional licensure. The second one is a big one, because it's what sets an IT professional apart from, say, a medical doctor, a professional engineer, lawyer, or a CPA. The educational requirements for licensure in some of these fields represent a high barrier to entry for foreigners who might otherwise be qualified to do the work. 12 posted on 12/02/2025 8:57:07 AM PST by Alberta's Child ("There's somebody new and he sure ain't no rodeo man.")
